000-mvault/basic-fetch-quest-1.html.title: Basic Fetch Quest
000-mvault/basic-fetch-quest-1.html.description:
Go to Object Window -> Character -> click on Quest -> Right Click - New In the open window - Quest Data tab: Give ID Give the Quest Name Type: Side Quests Give a Priority 50 Remove Start Game Enabled Quest Completion XP - XPMiscQuestLowLvlSmaller
In Quest Stages tab: Set up the stages Stage 10 Papyrus Fragment: 1SetObjectiveDisplayed(10)Stage 20:1SetObjectiveCompleted(10)2SetObjectiveDisplayed(20)
Stage 30: First you need to set everything up. Follow the tutorial, then check out Method 2 down below to get the script for Stage 30.You need to have a reference to an object. Right-click → New Reference Alias
In the open Reference Alias window: Give Alias a name Click Specific Reference → Select Forced Reference
In the open window, Select Reference in Render Window
There, you click on the object in the world.In this tab, you need to reference an objective stage to your alias, so to say: Right-click on Target Ref → New → Select your alias FirstObjective (Usually it will default to the first alias it finds by itself) In the game, it will show the quest marker to the object the player needs to go to. To add a trigger box, go to Object Windows and find DefaultSetStageTriggerPlayerOnly and drag it into the world Put it where you want and press 2 to scale it Then double-click it and go to Scripts tab Double-click on defaultrefontriggerenter
We deleted the second trigger box from the first tutorial. Then we go to our quest file → Quest Aliases and open FirstObjective in the list of Alias Names.
Then check that everything is ok:
Sometimes you might get unknown things here. It's pretty rare generally and usually it solves itself when you hit "Yes" to that. But it's best to make sure.When you get those warnings, read them through, take them seriously, and consider what you're about to delete so you won't have any problems. For this tutorial, we're going to select a rare blow torch and put it on the ground.
Now you should create an activator. You can either select a HotelBell object:

Note I made a custom activator from static object by following this tutorial. I made it a phone. Note In the example bellow, the Bell's ID is called kgQuest_TurnInBell. Further in this tutorial, you'll see the name mxpQuest_TurnInBell.
OR,you can select the phone with the activator you've made previously on the workbench:
000-mvault/basic-fetch-quest-1.html.author: Maksim Ilinskii

000-mvault/dropbear-ssh-on-keenetic-logi.title: Dropbear ssh on Keenetic login without password 999
000-mvault/dropbear-ssh-on-keenetic-logi.description:
Yes, you can use a different key for testing without needing to delete the current key from either machine. Here’s how you can do it:If you don't already have a new key, you can generate one using:1ssh-keygen -t rsa -f "$env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\Your_KeyName"1ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -f "$env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\Your_KeyName"This will create a new private key (Your_KeyName) and a corresponding public key (Your_KeyName.pub) in your .ssh directory. -b 4096 specifies the key length (in bits), with 4096 being a stronger, more secure choice. -f specifies the filename where the private key will be stored. The shorter command will create the file with the default name id_rsa in C:\Users\UserName\.ssh folder:1ssh-keygen -t rsa with 2048 bit (standard, but lower security) Agent work only in the current session! If you want to start it on every session, you need to start it as a service. Skip this the following steps, and follow this instruction: Auto-start SSH Agent on every terminal session If you want to start the Agent temporary, follow the steps: Start the Agent, if it isn't started: 1eval $(ssh-agent) You can add the new key to the SSH agent without affecting the current key: 1ssh-add "$env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\id_rsa"This tells the SSH agent to use the new private key for authentication.1type ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub | ssh root@192.168.1.1 -p 222 "cat >> /opt/etc/dropbear/authorized_keys && chmod 700 /opt/etc/dropbear && chmod 600 /opt/etc/dropbear/authorized_keys" chmod 600 /opt/etc/dropbear/authorized_keys — 600 is the required permission for authorized_keys hmod 700 /opt/etc/dropbear — 700 is the required permission for the folder.
You might need to create it, though. Login to root@192.168.1.1, and do the following:1mkdir /opt/etc/dropbear && chmod 700 /opt/etc/dropbearTo check that it's created, use:1ls -a /opt/etc/dropbear1icacls C:\Users\maxpe\.ssh\dropbear_rsa_hostkey /grant "MAKSIM\maxpe:F" /inheritance:r If it didn't work:
Windows — Remove permissions from the file If you used the SSH agent, it will automatically use it:1ssh -v root@192.168.1.1 -p 222Or, if you prefer to manually specify the key without adding it to the agent:1ssh -v -i "$env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\id_rsa" root@192.168.1.1 -p 222 -v argument stands for "verbose" — it's showing you the log You do not have to delete the old key from either machine. Both the old key and the new key can be used independently. Dropbear will try to authenticate with whichever key is available on the client-side (via the SSH agent or specified with the -i flag).This allows you to test with a new key while keeping your original key intact. When you’re ready to switch back to the old key, you can either: Remove the new key from the SSH agent using ssh-add -d "$env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\new_key", or Simply specify the old key manually again. Let me know if you'd like more guidance!
Key-based authentication in OpenSSH for Windows | Microsoft Learn — Note the part about non-English localized versions of the operating systemand this can give an idea to create a variable: 1# Get the public key file generated previously on your client2$authorizedKey = Get-Content -Path $env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\id_ecdsa.pub34# Generate the PowerShell to be run remote that will copy the public key file generated previously on your client to the authorized_keys file on your server5$remotePowershell = "powershell Add-Content -Force -Path $env:ProgramData\ssh\administrators_authorized_keys -Value '''$authorizedKey''';icacls.exe ""$env:ProgramData\ssh\administrators_authorized_keys"" /inheritance:r /grant ""Administrators:F"" /grant ""SYSTEM:F"""67# Connect to your server and run the PowerShell using the $remotePowerShell variable8ssh username@domain1@contoso.com $remotePowershell

headers.heading: 1. Generate or Prepare a New Key:
2. Add the New Key to the SSH Agent:
3. Add the New Public Key to Dropbear:
4. Now we need to clean the key from ownerships
5. Use the New Key for SSH Login:
No Need to Remove the Old Key:

000-mvault/git-—-restore-only-deleted-(b.title: Git — Restore only deleted (but not modified) files
000-mvault/git-—-restore-only-deleted-(b.description:
Enter the command:1git log --diff-filter=D --name-only -- "attachments/image"The output would be something like that:1PS C:\Users\maxpe\Documents\WORK STATION\ObsidianVaults\ThoughtsTheHorses> git log --diff-filter=D --name-only -- "attachments/image"2commit 097046f88d2ffc14b24b35a506b4b574ee0241eb3Author: Maxim Pokrovsky <maxpere3@gmail.com>4Date: Sun Dec 15 12:25:22 2024 +030056 vault backup: 2024-12-15 12:25:2278attachments/image/2020-10-26_005749.jpeg9attachments/image/2020-10-26_005821-e1616489818790.jpeg10"attachments/image/Skyrim \342\200\224 How to change the mod's master dependency file-1718133164080.jpeg"11"attachments/image/Skyrim \342\200\224 How to change the mod's master dependency file-1718133232678.jpeg"12"attachments/image/Skyrim \342\200\224 How to change the mod's master dependency file-1718133407910.jpeg"13attachments/image/Untitled 2-1732858735166.jpeg14attachments/image/Untitled 2-1732858735262.jpeg15attachments/image/Untitled 2-1732858735300.jpeg16attachments/image/Untitled 2-1732858735536.jpeg17attachments/image/Untitled 2-1732858735799.jpeg18attachments/image/Untitled 2-1732858735871.jpeg19attachments/image/Untitled 2-1732858736001.jpeg20attachments/image/Untitled 2-1732858736878.jpeg2122commit d080c53405e0ffb4152fd237717e3dbb169a611923Author: d0verenny <maxpere3@gmail.com>24Date: Tue Feb 27 13:24:36 2024 +03002526 vault backup: 2024-02-27 13:24:362728"attachments/image/AE \342\200\224 Projection Maping-1709023976166.jpeg"2930commit 70a3e66f9d7496435d23b0bb794a282d83b893ff31Author: Maksim <maxpere3@gmail.com>32Date: Tue Aug 30 01:05:38 2022 +03003334 vault backup: 2022-08-30 01:05:383536attachments/image/Obsidian Dashboard-1661626838969.jpeg37attachments/image/Van Der Hooven-1661755170391.jpeg38attachments/image/Van Der Hooven-1661755170605.jpegList all the deleted files in the attachments/image directory:1git diff --name-only --diff-filter=D -- attachments/imageList doesn't mean you'll see it on the screen! For that, you should use log command from step 1
There are 2 environments where you can do that on Windows: powershell, or git bash. And there are 2 options to do that. 1$deletedFiles = git diff --name-only --diff-filter=D -- "attachments/image"2foreach ($file in $deletedFiles) {3 git restore --source=<commit_hash> --staged -- $file4}Use the commit hash from the log you've seen on step 1, instead of the <commit_hash>. E.g: 097046f88d2ffc14b24b35a506b4b574ee0241eb1$deletedFiles = git diff --name-only --diff-filter=D -- attachments/image2foreach ($file in $deletedFiles) {3 git restore --source=097046f88d2ffc14b24b35a506b4b574ee0241eb --staged -- $file4}
Step 1: The command git diff --name-only --diff-filter=D -- attachments/image lists all deleted files in the attachments/image directory.
Step 2: The loop (foreach) iterates over each deleted file.
Step 3: The git restore command is run for each file, using a specific commit hash (<commit_hash>). The commit hash can be one you manually choose (for example, the commit where the file was last present).
Result: Each deleted file is restored from one specific commit (the commit hash you provide).
1$deletedFiles = git diff --name-only --diff-filter=D -- "attachments/image"2$commitHashes = git rev-list --all34foreach ($commitHash in $commitHashes) {5 foreach ($file in $deletedFiles) {6 git restore --source=$commitHash --staged -- $file7 }8}9
Step 1: The command git diff --name-only --diff-filter=D -- attachments/image lists all deleted files in the attachments/image directory (same as in Code No. 1).
Step 2: The command git rev-list --all retrieves all commit hashes in the repository (from the entire commit history).
Step 3: The outer foreach loop iterates through all commits (from $commitHashes).
Step 4: The inner foreach loop iterates through each of the deleted files.
Step 5: The git restore command restores each deleted file from every commit one by one.
Result: Each deleted file is restored from every commit in the repository where it exists (even if it was deleted in a later commit). This can result in multiple restorations for the same file.
1# List deleted files in attachments/image2deletedFiles=$(git diff --name-only --diff-filter=D -- attachments/image)34# Loop through each deleted file and restore it from a specific commit5for file in $deletedFiles; do6 git restore --source=<commit_hash> --staged -- "$file"7done8
Variable assignment: In Git Bash, you use $(...) for command substitution, which works similarly to $() in PowerShell.
Looping: The for file in $deletedFiles; do ... done loop is standard in Bash for iterating through a list of items.
Restoring: The git restore command is the same, but ensure to replace <commit_hash> with the actual commit hash.
1# List deleted files in attachments/image2deletedFiles=$(git diff --name-only --diff-filter=D -- attachments/image)34# Get all commit hashes in the repository5commitHashes=$(git rev-list --all)67# Loop through each commit hash and each deleted file8for commitHash in $commitHashes; do9 for file in $deletedFiles; do10 git restore --source=$commitHash --staged -- "$file"11 done12done
Variable assignment: Again, use $(...) for both the $deletedFiles and $commitHashes variables.
Looping: We use nested for loops to iterate over each commit hash and each deleted file.
Restoring: The git restore command works the same way, restoring the deleted files from each commit. Variable assignment: In Bash, you assign values to variables without $ in front of the variable name when assigning (e.g., deletedFiles=...), and you use $ to reference them when used.
Looping: The syntax for loops in Bash is for item in $list; do ... done, whereas PowerShell uses foreach ($item in $list) { ... }.

headers.heading: Step 1: Check the list of deleted files
Option A: To restore from a SPECIFIC COMMIT:
Option B: To restore from ALL COMMITS
Now the same commands FOR GIT BASH:
Option A: To restore from a SPECIFIC COMMIT
Option B: To restore from ALL COMMITS
Key Differences in Bash and Poweshell:

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_siteName.description: The name of the vault / exported site

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
